snippet: Analysts say Syrian officials are unsure who would benefit militarily if the United States launches strikes against ISIS in Syria — government forces, or Syrian insurgents and separatist Kurds.
abstract: Syrian Pres Bashar al-Assad and his allies see political advantage in Pres Obama's declaration that he may strike in Syria against extremist group Islamic State in Iraq and Syria; some analysts, however, have expressed concern that strikes may benefit rival insurgent groups more than Syrian government.

byline.contributor: Hwaida Saad and Mohammad Ghannam contributed reporting from Beirut, and an employee of The New York Times from Raqqa, Syria.

lead_paragraph: Analysts say Syrian officials are unsure who would benefit militarily if the United States launches strikes against ISIS in Syria — government forces, or Syrian insurgents and separatist Kurds.

headline.main: Syrian Leaders See Opportunities and Risks in U.S. Striking ISIS on Their Soil
headline.print_headline: Syrian Leaders See Opportunities and Risks in U.S. Striking ISIS on Their Soil
